gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
When using this data set, it should be bibliographically referred to as 'GISCO NUTS 2003'.
The 'GISCO NUTS 2003' dataset represents the NUTS regions by means of region, arc and point topology. The NUTS geographical information is completed by attribute tables and a set of cartographic help lines to better visualise multipart polygonal regions.
The NUTS nomenclature is a hierarchical classification of statistical regions defined by Eurostat. The NUTS classification subdivides the EU economic territory into 3 statistical levels.
The Regulation (EC) No 1059/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a common classification of territorial units for statistics (NUTS) was enforced the 11 July 2003. This regulation provided the NUTS classification with a legal background.
Since then, 12 new countries joined the European Union. The NUTS regulation was officially enforced in these 12 countries the day of their accession to the EU.
A non official NUTS-like classification has been defined for the EFTA countries, Croatia and Turkey.
For further information about the NUTS classification please check the RAMON Eurostat site at http://ec.europa.eu/comm/eurostat/ramon/nuts/home_regions_en.html
At present, five scale ranges (100K, 1M, 3M, 10M and 20M) are maintained in the GISCO geodatabase. The scale levels 1M to 20M are preliminary data and do not have the same data source as the 100K version (= official version). The polygon and boundary classes delineate the regions while the points provide a label for each region. Associated tables contain basic information such as the region's name.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Data on administrative boundaries represent a fundamental element of almost any GIS. In the context of the GISCO information system, the NUTS boundaries data are a vital part of the geographic framework, providing means for registering data to regional territories. Equally, national and regional boundaries are essential components of the cartographic backdrop giving a recognisable geographic context to cartographic outputs.

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: Area Management/restriction/regulation zones and reporting units

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Directive 20007/.../EC/ of the European parliament and of the Council of establishing an Infrastructure for Spatial Information in the European Community (INSPIRE)

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: The datasets have been created for cartographic purposes.

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Usage of data is restricted to specific conditions, that can be found on the data download page and in the metadata for each individual class and table.

gmd:orderingInstructions.gco:CharacterString: Address to the point of contact specified in this metadata

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: All feature classes, attribute tables and relationship classes should be present

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: All feature classes, attribute tables and relationship classes are present

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: The integrity and cardinality of the relationships (conceptual and implemented) was checked by enforcing primary and foreign key integrity constraints in Oracle. The constraints referencing coded value domain tables were a test of domain consistency.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Errors will show during creation of integrity constraints in Oracle. Constraints will not be applicable in case of violations to the consistency.

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: No errors occurred, so the integrity of all primary and foreign keys was confirmed. All the values of each coded value attribute are compliant to the domains (except for any NULL values). The cardinality can only be confirmed where it is strict enough for this test to detect errors.

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Consistency within NUTS regions of the same level

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: Nuts regions of the same level should not overlap each other

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: No topology errors identified, so no overlapping regions within each nuts level

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Consistency of NUTS boundary feature class

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: Nuts boundaries must not have dangles, must not overlap, must not self-intersect, must not intersect or touch interior and must be singlepart

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Consistency between NUTS regions and NUTS boundaries

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: NUTS_BN_100K_2003 Must be covered by boundary of NUTS_RG_100K_2003
NUTS_BN_100K_2003 Must be covered by feature class of COMM_BN_2004

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: Errors in Scotland (GRO) and Slovenia but these are known exceptions in the NUTS classification.

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: NUTS_LB_2003 Must be properly inside a polygon in NUTS_RG_100K_2003 with the same NUTS_ID

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: No real errors found, all indicated labels outside a region belong to archipelagos

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: NUTS_RG_100K_2003: Boundary must be covered by COMM_BN_2004

gmd:explanation.gco:CharacterString: Errors in Scotland (GRO) and Slovenia but these are known exceptions in the NUTS classification

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
The NUTS 2003 at scale level 1:100 000 (together with the other datasets: COMM_2004, CNTR_2004 and HYDR_2004) are based on geometry of EBM 2004 v1.1. of EuroGeographics. So the datasets COMM_2004, CNTR_2004, HYDR_2004 and NUTS_2003 (100K) are fully coherent and compliant.
The boundaries and regions for the 100K scale level are related to each other through a relationship table. This dataset is the final reference dataset for the NUTS 2003 classification
The NUTS 2003 scale versions 1:1m, 1:3m, 1:10m and 1:20m are based on EuroBoundary Map 2001 v1.1. These four small scale version should be used exclusively for cartographic purposes and they present small differences with the 100k version due to the changes in the administrative boundaries between 2001 and 2004 (reference date of the sources)
The NUTS boundaries and the regions were created as separated feature classes and exist at 4 different scale levels (1:1; 1:3; 1:10 and 1:20 Million) all derived from the 1:1 Million dissolved dataset.
A labelpoint feature class was created with a label inside each NUTS region at the 4 NUTS levels (0 - 3).
A line feature class was created for cartograhic joiners to identify where NUTS areas have one or more enclaves. Also a line feature class for cartographic separators was created to identify where the NUTS limits are in the archipelagos. The arcs of two latter feature classes are only useful for cartographic purposes and are not meant to identify actual administrative or statistical boundaries stretching into the sea or any other significance.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: (i) Eurogeographics SABE and SCOLE data v1.1. (scale 1:1M) -- for scale levels 1M to 20M (ii) Eurogeographics EBM 2004 v1.1. and SCOLE data (scale 1:100K) -- for scale level 100K (iii) CLC2000 vector data for (Elbe, Weser, Garonne, Ringkoebingfjord) -- for scale level 100K (iv) GRO (General Register Office for Scotland 2003) -- for scale level 100K (v) NUTS nomenclature supplied by EUROSTAT -- for all scale levels

gmd:definition.gco:CharacterString: NUTS 2003 region topology (= Multipart polygon) scale 1:20 milllion.
NUTS 2003 region topology (= Multipart polygon) scale 1:10 milllion.
NUTS 2003 region topology (= Multipart polygon) scale 1:3 milllion.
NUTS 2003 region topology (= Multipart polygon) scale 1:10 milllion.
NUTS 2003 boundaries, arc topology, scale 1:20 milllion.
NUTS 2003 boundaries, arc topology, scale 1:1 milllion.
NUTS 2003 boundaries, arc topology, scale 1:3 milllion.
NUTS 2003 boundaries, arc topology, scale 1:10 milllion.
NUTS 2003 region topology (= Multipart polygon) scale 1:100 000.

NUTS 2003 joiners, arc topology.
A joiner is a line to visually connect an exclave to the main region where it belongs. A joiner has only cartographic purposes.

NUTS 2003 separators, arc topology.
A separator is a line to visually group or divide sea areas into regions. A separator are not meant to represent administrative boundaries. Separators are designed only for cartographic purposes.
Implementation of the many-to-many relationship between features in NUTS_RG_100K_2003 and NUTS_BN_100K_2003

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Regulation (EC) No 1059/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of a common classification of territorial units for statistics (NUTS)
